#Text=J. W. Lonoaea
#Text=Representatives William Thomas Martin and William Luther Moehonua , survivors of the attack on the legislative assembly .
#Text=Gatling guns and soldiers landed to quell the violent mob during the 1874 election riot
#Text=J.W. Lonoaea ( died March 16 , 1874 ) was a politician of the Kingdom of Hawaiʻi who served in the House of Representatives of the Legislature of the Kingdom from 1872 until his death . [ 1 ]

#Text=Following the death of King Lunalilo , it fell to the legislature to choose the next monarch from amongst the native-born high chiefs , though only three candidates were considered seriously : Bernice Pauahi Bishop , David Kalākaua , and Queen Emma . [ 2 ]
#Text=Lonoaea voted with the majority in supporting Kalākaua , and was one of the thirteen legislators to be injured by supporters of Queen Emma in the ensuing 1874 Honolulu Courthouse riot . [ 3 ]
#Text=Lonoaea was the only legislator who did not survive his injuries . [ 4 ]
#Text=Life and career
#Text=Lonoaea entered the service of the Hawaiian government during the last year of the reign of King Kamehameha V .

#Text=His election as a member of the House of Representatives the lower house of the Hawaiian legislature ) for the district of Wailuku on the island of Maui was reported on February 14 , 1872 ; he was re-elected in 1874 for a second term . [ 1 ]
#Text=He served as a representative from 1872 to 1874 , including the regular biennial session of 1872 and the two extra sessions ( called to elect the monarch ) in 1873 and 1874 . [ 5 ] [ 6 ]

#Text=King Kamehameha V was the ruling monarch at when Lonoaea began his first legislative term , but died at the end of 1872 ; having no heir , the 1864 Constitution of the Kingdom of Hawaii called for the legislature to select the next monarch .
#Text=By both popular vote and the unanimous decision of the legislators , Lunalilo became the first elected king of Hawaii . [ 7 ]
#Text=1874 election and riot

#Text=On February 12 , 1874 , following the death of King Lunalilo , a special session was called to elect a new monarch from amongst the aliʻi ; this was the second time in Hawaiian history that this duty fell to the legislature .
#Text=During the election that followed , David Kalākaua ran against Queen Emma , the widow of Kamehameha IV who had reigned until his death in 1863 . [ 8 ]
#Text=Bernice Pauahi Bishop , who had previously declined the throne in 1872 when it was offered by Kamehameha V , was also considered .
#Text=During the session , Lonoaea offered opening prayers before legislative president Paul Nahaolelua took the chair .
#Text=The assembly voted thirty-nine to six in favor of Kalākaua over Emma . [ 9 ] [ 10 ]
#Text=The subsequent announcement triggered the Honolulu Courthouse riot as Emmaite supporters hunted down and attacked native legislators who supported Kalākaua .
#Text=Historian Jon Kamakawiwoʻole Osorio noted that " the attacks were conducted by Natives against Natives over issues of loyalty and kanaka identity " . [ 11 ]
#Text=The rioters targeted mainly these men , tearing apart the courthouse and creating makeshift clubs to use as bludgeons .
#Text=One legislator was thrown from a second-story window of the courthouse .
#Text=In order to quell the civil disruption , American and British troops were landed with the permission of the Hawaiian government , and the rioters were arrested . [ 12 ]
#Text=Death
#Text=Lonoaea was one of thirteen legislators injured during the riot by supporters of Queen Emma .

#Text=The local Hawaiian newspapers reported that only Representatives Kipi , Haupu , Nahinu , Kakani and Moehonua were " severely injured " or " dangerously injured " , receiving blows to their heads , while the injuries of Lonoaea and others were reported as less severe . [ 13 ]
#Text=He returned to his home in Wailuku to recover but was ultimately the only legislator not to recover from his injuries .
#Text=With travel and communications slow between the islands of Oahu and Maui , news from Wailuku took time to reach Honolulu .
#Text=The Hawaiian Gazette prematurely reported Lonoaea 's death on March 6 , which The Pacific Commercial Advertiser had to correct .
#Text=Lonoaea actually died from his injuries on March 16 , 1874 , at his home on Wailuku , but news confirming his passing did not reach Honolulu until five days later .
#Text=His seat in the legislative session and his duties representing Wailuku were taken over by N. Kepoikai . [ 14 ]
#Text=Later the same year , the legislature allotted a four-hundred-dollar permanent settlement to Lonoaea 's wife . [ 15 ]
